comments.author: vexx32
comments.body: @sidsolutions-net the Test-NetConnection command is only available from the Windows PowerShell `NetTCPIP` module. You'll need to have the Windows PowerShell module loaded to be able to use the command. You may need to make sure your Windows PowerShell module locations are present in $env:PSModulePath to be able to load the module by name, otherwise you can always load it directly by the full path.

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body:
In latest builds you can load Core incompatible modules in background Windows PowerShell session (#10973):
```powershell
Import-Module -UseWindowsPowerShell NetTCPIP
```

comments.author: vexx32
comments.body:
The NetTCPIP is a Windows module, it doesn't exist for Linux, and likely will not be able to be ported as it uses Windows-OS-specific APIs for its functionality.

You can use the pwsh-native `Test-Connection` cmdlet on any OS pwsh is available on. However, I will note that .NET Core / .NET 5 support for parts of the functionality it implements is rather lacking in places, so depending on your use case it may be more desirable to use a linux-native ping application.

Refer to these issues for fix timelines in .NET Core:

* https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/issues/29984 (fixed!)
* https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/issues/927 (seemingly abandoned?)
